node.title: adCoupledGradient in FV interface kernel

node.bodyText:
Hello
Are you trying to build your own gradient?
We have the following ways to get you gradients here:

var1().grad(face_arg) and var2().grad(face_arg) for face gradients
var1().grad(elem_arg) and var2().grad(neighbor_arg) for element gradients

elem or face_arg are built from elem/neighborFromFace() routine and singleSidedFaceArg routine
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume,
Thanks.! Yes, using
ADRealVectorValue gradient_diff = var1().adGradSln(&_face_info->elem())-var2().adGradSln(_face_info->neighborPtr)));
seems to work to generate a difference in gradients across the interface. At least the compiler does not puke.
I also need to generate differences of nonlinear variables, say mag_x, across the interface. I managed (I think) to generate differences between elemental values using
params.addRequiredParam("mag_x",  );
..
_mag_x(getFunctor("mag_x")),
...
const auto mag_x_diff = _mag_x(elemFromFace()) - _mag_x(neighborFromFace());
that is, I passed the nonlinear variable as an adFunctor so I could access the elemFromFace routine. I could not use the adSln(&_face_info->elem()) for the functor or if I pass the nonlinear variable as adCoupledValue. I am not sure if it makes sense to pass the nonlinear variable mag_x as a functor. And alternative, I guess, would be to build up the interface residual by running twice with var1 and var2 being the different nonlinear variables in each call, but that seems a little clumsy.

Retrieving it as a functor allows you to use, in addition to variables:

functions
functor material property
That s not useful to everyone. Many will still want to retrieve a pointer to the variable.

The flux is supposed to be the same on both sides of the interface right? Like there is conservation of whatever quantity is going through the face?
Note that coupledValue() does not allow to use the functor routines. This is for retrieving variable values the traditional way only

OK, so I can retrieve the nonlinear variable as a functor - cool! No, the flux is not conserved across the interface - the gradient of the potential has a discontinuity across the interface with sources related to the nonlinear variable mag_x.

Oh, I see. So I would need to be able to add two different pieces, one from each side of the interface. I can arrange so that computeQpResidual in my interface kernel calculates and returns the contributions from both sides of the interface. Would there be an easy way for me to modify my FVInterfaceKernel so the contribution I have calculated just get multiplied by the appropriate face area (without adding equal and opposite contributions from each side)?

you ll need to overwrite ComputeResidual to make that change. computeQpResidual is only called once right now, so even if you have the right logic for distinguishing, it wont contribute a different amount on both sides
It's not where we want to be in the future but it should be doable now

I'll give it a shot....
Thanks again for your help!
we could make a virtual computeNeighborQpResidual whose base implementation just returns the negative of computeQpResidual
Although that is kind of wasteful ... in most cases it would perform the AD computeQpResidual computation twice
I've created issue #22610 for this

node.title: How do I apply two load levels in a Multi-stage creep test in MOOSE?
node.bodyText:
Hello, I’m performing a multi-stage creep test with two applied load levels. However, I can’t figure out how to apply this load conditions. Any clue will help. Thanks. Here is my input file:
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 1
  ny = 1
  nz = 1
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [damage_param]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
   [kelvin_creep_rate]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
   [damage_evol]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    variable = damage_param
    property = damage_param
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
    [kelvin_creep_rate_evol]
    type = MaterialRealAux
    variable = kelvin_creep_rate
    property = kelvin_creep_rate
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_end'
  []
[]


[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [all]
    strain = SMALL
    incremental = true
    add_variables = true 
    generate_output = 'stress_yy creep_strain_xx creep_strain_yy creep_strain_zz elastic_strain_yy' 
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [top_pull]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 1'
    y = '1 1'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [u_top_pull]
    type = Pressure
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = top
    factor = '-10.0e6'
    function = top_pull
  []
  [u_bottom_fix]
    type = DirichletBC

    boundary = bottom

  [u_yz_fix]
    type = DirichletBC

    value = 0.0

  [u_xy_fix]
    type = DirichletBC

[]


[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 2e10     # 2e11
    poissons_ratio = 0.3      # 0.3
  []
  [radial_return_stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'LuxWolters_Eps'
    tangent_operator = elastic
    combined_inelastic_strain_weights = '1.0'
  []
  [LuxWolters_Eps]
    type = LuxWoltersEps
    mvM =  -2.47e-6            
    etaM0 = 2.03e7           
    mvK =   -1.68e-6           
    mk =    -1.91e-6           
    etaK0 =  8.94e3            
    GK0 =    5.08e5          
      a4 = 0.3
      a5 = 0.05
      a6 = 67.0
      a7 = 41.0
      a8 = 0.25
      a9 = 1.0
     a10 = 0.25
     a15 = 1.67e-1
     a16 = 1.0e-8
     a17 = 3.5e-8
     sigma0 = 1.0
       L= 5.5E-2
      L1= 0.0
       T= 333
       a = 0
       b = 0
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'PJFNK' 

  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = '101'
  line_search = 'none'
  automatic_scaling = true
  computing_scaling_once = false

  l_max_its = 20
  nl_max_its = 20
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
  l_tol = 1e-5

  end_time = 100.0
  num_steps = 100
  dt = 0.001
[]

[Postprocessors]
    [elastic]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1 1 1'
    variable = elastic_strain_yy
  []
    [creep_strainXX]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1 1 1'
    variable = creep_strain_xx
  []
    [creep_strainYY]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1 1 1'
    variable = creep_strain_yy
  []
    [creep_strainZZ]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1 1 1'
    variable = creep_strain_zz
  []
    [stressYY]
    type = PointValue
    point = '1 1 1'
    variable = stress_yy
  []

   type = PointValue
   point = '1 1 1'
   variable = damage_param
  []

   variable = kelvin_creep_rate

Hello
What do you mean exactly by two load levels? I m not sure
maybe @hugary1995 will know what you mean
Guillaume

I suppose you mean two different magnitudes of load for two periods of time. You can change the top_pull function in your input file. For example,
[Functions]
  [top_pull]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 1 2'
    y = '1 1 2'
  []
[]
There are many, many different ways of specifying a function in MOOSE. Please consult the documentation.

Thanks, @hugary1995 . Exactly, I want to apply two magnitudes of loads at two time periods, but the second time period should begin after the first test occurred. That means the second load will initiate a new test. I tried using the PiecewiseLinear function before but came up with a graph showing only one load level (test).

if they are one after the other, you can bake both profiles into the same function.
This can be easily done with a parsed expression in a ParsedFunction if you need some flexibility

I tried using the PiecewiseLinear function before but came up with a graph showing only one load level (test).

hmm, interesting. So are you suggesting PiecewiseLinear gave you a different function than what you specified?
@GiudGiud  @hugary1995. I made some  adjustments to the Piecewiselinear. Both methods worked! I'm, however, sticking with the PiecewiseLinear function. Thanks. 👍
Yep, and if you don't want to manually control the "ramping" from one load to another, there is also a PiecewiseConstant object.

node.title: The following material properties are declared on block 1 by multiple materials:
node.bodyText:
Hi！
I am trying to add Thermal and Irradiation Creep with PowerLawCreepStressUpdate.
It works fine when I add one, but adding two at the same time causes an error.
    [./creep1]
    type = PowerLawCreepStressUpdate
    activation_energy = 52000
    temperature = T
    coefficient = 5000
    n_exponent = 1
  [../]
    [./creep2]
    type = PowerLawCreepStressUpdate
    activation_energy = 52000
    temperature = T
    coefficient = 6
    n_exponent = 4.5
  [../]

The following material properties are declared on block 1 by multiple materials:
  Material Property             Material Objects
  creep_strain                  all_strain creep1 creep2 stress vonmises_stress_all 
  effective_creep_strain        all_strain creep1 creep2 stress vonmises_stress_all
You'll have to use different base names.
Thanks a lot ！Your answer solves my problem perfectly ！

node.title: Defining creep rate with a custom function
node.bodyText: I have creep rate data as a function of temperature and shear stress in a table. After importing this data as a bilinear interpolation function is there a way to utilize this function for modeling creep? Or would a custom kernel need to be written for this?
@bwspenc @recuero

So something similar to this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/PowerLawCreepStressUpdate.html
but not power law?

Yes, in this case I don't have access to fitted power law parameters and instead just have creep rates that result from a combination of shear stress and temperature. The data covers several different creep regimes, which would make simple power law fitting inapplicable.

If your use case doesn't use a power law and directly prescribes the creep rate as a function of some variables, I'd create a new creep object which takes a function with a number of parameters, some of them may be optional. So, I don't think you need a kernel but a material property.
Would you be willing to provide a simple example of the implementation of that in a MOOSE input file?

I don't think we currently have that capability in MOOSE (I may be missing some options though). So I don't think you can prescribe that from the input file; you'd need an a creep object that takes Functions as input parameters and operate on them with coupled variables to return the creep rate that your data represents. You could define a function in the input file that takes parameters as temperature and then pass the function to such an object. There are objects that take functions, such as: ComputeDynamicFrictionalForceLMMechanicalContact with
params.addParam<FunctionName>(
      "function_friction",
      "Coupled function to evaluate friction with values from contact pressure and relative "
      "tangential velocities (from the previous step).");

Pulling a variable dependent function into an object seems simple enough.
I assume that any creep object is going to follow a similar structure to the other StressUpdate objects in order to work with ComputeMultipleInelasticStress.  Can I follow the structure of the ComputeMultipleInelasticStress source file as a reference or would some of the quantities computed in that file be unnecessary in my implementation?

I would follow the same structure as other stress update objects that work with ComputeMultipleInelasticStress. There are a number of capabilities associated with that object: substepping, management of various inelasticity sources, tangent operator, etc.

Gotcha thank you! I was able to build the custom object and get reasonable values for my creep rate, but I am struggling to get the simulation to converge with the object active. Is there an effective way or recommended approach to debug this?
Exceeded maximum iterations in material return mapping iterations.
At element 0 _qp=0 Coordinates (x,y,z)=(-0.000781231, 0.0013792, 0.00186622) block=1
In 1000 iterations the residual went from 1.53452e+07 to 3.35603e+11 in 'FrostPowerLawCreep'.

To follow up on this, I have pivoted from pulling from a lookup table and am instead using fitted function to compute my creep rate in the form: $$A * \sigma^n * exp\left(\frac{-Q_1}{RT}\right) + B * \sigma^m * exp\left(\frac{-Q_2}{RT}\right)$$
I believe I have implemented it correctly, but I continue to get the above error when running it. Although the residual just is often more extreme as shown below.

am instead using fitted function to compute my creep rate in the form

You are probably then using MOOSE's capabilities, which allow to combine power law functions.

The number of substeps will depend on the criterion used to perform substepping. If the tolerance you used for that is okay, this message probably means your time step is too large.

node.title: How to build a model of two blocks without gaps？
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I wonder how to build a model of two blocks without gaps？My mesh is merged by  two mesh files with ICEM.

I want to simulate heat conduction between two blocks. And when I use GapHeatTransfer, it`s not work in this no-gap condition.
When adding Tensor Mechanics, it has gaps between blocks.

I wonder how to creat a whole  Heat Conduction and Tensor Mechanics  Mesh with tow different materials blocks.
Thanks in advance for your help!
If the nodes on each mesh align you could use the StitchedMeshGenerator to merge the nodes of the two meshes, making them connected for the physics 👍
Thanks a lot ！Your answer solves my problem perfectly ！

Hello
You may want to use ThinLayerHeatTransfer in the connected situation instead of the GapHeatTransfer
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/interfacekernels/ThinLayerHeatTransfer.html
Guillaume

Thanks a lot ！ I use the StitchedMeshGenerator, set heat source in block 1, and find heat transfer in block 2.  And when adding Tensor Mechanics, it has no gaps between blocks! My problem is solved perfectly!

node.title: Normal stress-  error: 'declareProperty' was not declared in this scope

node.bodyText:
Hello
declareProperty is for material properties, defined (and declared) in Materials.
You are writing an auxkernel here.
Maybe you meant to retrieve a material property instead? With getMaterialProperty
Guillaume

Hi,
Sorry for late back, actually, my purpose is to use normal vector of element face by applying "_normals". Already, the normal vector was used in "PressureBC" and here by @ngrilli.
So, based on these and your suggestion, I editted my Auxkernel:
1- I used " const MooseArray & _normals; " instead of "const MaterialProperty  & _normals;" in .h file.
2- and, " _normals(_assembly.normals("_normals"))," instead of declarying "_normals(declareProperty("_normals")),".
Now, It is linked to my App, but once I am running a simple example,  it shows following error:

Please see the FAQ page for debugging suggestions

[./direction2]

Ok so what is line 47 in TigerMohrCoulombFailure?
Would it be possible to give me access to tiger?

The line 47:  return MetaPhysicL::raw_value (_normals[_qp] * (_TenMech_total_stress[_qp]) * (_normals[_qp]));
where _normals refers to normal vector on element face and _tenMech_total_stress gets stress state in current time step, which calculates normal stress. I other words, it returns the multiplication: vector * matrix* vector.
Also, you can see .c file on top of the discussion.
Regarding your access to tiger, I should say that tiger is already commit https://github.com/MGK-Lab/tiger, but failure criterion is being developed by this auxkernel.

mamba activate peacock

Hi，I've already installed MOOSE in the same way of the official website, but peacock doesn't work. Then I followed the instructions and created a separate environment to install peacock. This is what I have done so far. Do I need to reinstall the MOOSE in this separate environment just to use peacock? Thank you for your reply!

no you should keep both moose and peacock in their separate environments.
You can either:

run MOOSE in peacock from the peacock mamba environment. Since MOOSE was installed in the moose environment, it knows where to find most of the libraries it needs, even though they are not in the peacock mamba environment. (the only issue in my mind could be which MPI gets used)
run MOOSE in its moose mamba environment, read the results from another terminal tab in a peacock environment

We do that because the dependencies of each are often conflicting.

Couldn't show a VTK window.
This is most likely caused by outdated Mesa drivers.
You can try upgrading to Mesa version 10.6.5 or later or update your video card driver.
If you are running in a virtual machine, you can try turning OFF 3D acceleration.

You can also try to use an alternative VTK package in a conda environment.
You can create a new conda environment by doing (with the miniconda module loaded):

	conda create --clone root -n <env_name>
	source activate <env_name>
	conda install -c https://conda.software.inl.gov/public vtk=7.1.1.opengl

Then you can try running peacock again.
Note that this VTK package may have various rendering problems and some peacock tests will fail.

I believe those instructions are deprecated. There is no 'vtk' package available on our /public channel... The best place to actually use Peacock will be on your personal workstation, where hardware rendering is available.

OK - thanks for confirming.  I have tried to use Peacock on a Windows desktop via WSL2/Ubuntu, but it just 'segmentation faults'; not sure if it's the WSL2 aspect or if the PC is underpowered.
One solution, that worked for me, has been to download Paraview onto my PC and use that to view the *.e files that the MOOSE training course generates.

I imagine our instructions for WSL(2) are severely out of date. I've been working from home lately (feeling under the weather); I can try to run Peacock on my gaming rig, see if I can reproduce the issue and attempt a a fix.
What version of Ubuntu are you using? I'd like to simulate your environment as close as possible.

Software:
Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
VcXsrv 1.20.13.0
OS:
Windows 10 22H2 Build 19045.2311
Hardware:
Intel i5-2500K @ 3.30 GHz
8GB RAM
NVIDIA GTx 660

After some trial and error, I was able to get Peacock to launch. Things certainly have changed since I last visited running Peacock on WSL(2).
From what I am reading, Windows 11 folks will enjoy native GL support without needing to Install VcXsrv. Their only pre-requisite is to install their optimized video card drivers (NVIDIA or AMD). While the rest of us still on Windows 10 continue to need VcXsrv. Considering myself something of a power user, even I was confused on Microsof's literature about WSL2/native GL support (but not on Windows 10).
Windows 10 has changed somewhat from when I last created WSL instructions. Instead of export DISPLAY=localhost:0, it is now necessary to export your native host's IP address. I also found it necessary to disable access control when launching VcXsrv.
Here's precisely everything I did:

Open PowerShell as an Administrator, and update WSL, set version to 2, restart it:
PS C:\Windows\system32> wsl --update
PS C:\Windows\system32> wsl --set-default-version 2
PS C:\Windows\system32> wsl --shutdown

Installed Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS using Microsoft Store
Installed VcXsrv and launched it with the following changes



Launch Ubuntu 22.04.1 and perform the following commands:
sudo apt-get udpate
sudo apt-get upgrade
sudo apt-get install x11-apps libglu1-mesa libgl1-mesa-glx
curl -L -O https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Mambaforge-Linux-x86_64.sh
bash Mambaforge-Linux-x86_64.sh -b -p ~/mambaforge3
export PATH=~/mambaforge3/bin:$PATH
mamba init
exit

Launch Ubuntu 22.04.1 again, and perform the following commands:
mamba install openssl=1
conda config --add channels https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
mamba create -n moose moose-libmesh moose-tools
mamba create -n peacock moose-peacock python=3.10
mamba activate moose
mkdir ~/projects; cd ~/projects
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose
cd moose
git checkout master
cd test
make -j 16
cd tests/geomsearch/3d_moving_penetration
mamba activate peacock
export DISPLAY=192.168.158.146:0
../../../../python/peacock/peacock -i pl_test1.i


Obviously other's IP addresses will be different.
I am going to go ahead and post this. And run through it again using a fresh Ubuntu 22.04. I may have missed an apt-get install.

Okay, went through the above again, after re-installing my Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS, is a success.
The bit about LIBGL_ALWAYS_INDIRECT, I don't seem to need to do.
I don't mean for you to go through all this over again, but if you have the time! I would love to hear about your results.

I went through those steps, but still got the segmentation fault.  I've dumped the output from strace into this file:
segfault.txt
I did have an issue with this line:
sudo apt-get install x11-apps libglu1-mesa libglu1-mesa-glx

Which raised the error:
E: Unable to locate package libglu1-mesa-glx

Which I attempted to get around by install mesa-utils, i.e. following these instructions:
How to Upgrade Mesa Drivers on Ubuntu 22.04 LTS
I also changed make -j 16 to make -j 4 due to my PC hardware limitations.

Sorry I didn't expect anyone to follow my instructions until I posted again, that they worked. The package you need is libgl1-mesa-glx and not libglu1-mesa-glx that I mistakenly placed (and fixed on my second attempt).
also, something quick to try to make sure VcXsrv is installed and working: Try and run xeyes from your Ubuntu terminal (after export DISPLAY=<your IP address>:0

No problem.  I've installed libgl1-mesa-glx now, but it still segmentation faults.  I'm going to asasume it's my ancient hardware and stick to using Paraview for now, but thanks for your help.
VcXsrv has always worked; I've been useing Nedit, gedit, Nautilus etc. without problem.
